questions.text: A chronic alcoholic was admitted to the hospital for 2 days. On the 3rd day, the doctor noted agitation, confusion, disorientation, hallucination, hypertension, and sweating. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Delirium tremens

 

Delirium tremens (DT) is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that usually occurs 2 to 3 days after the last drink. It is characterized by agitation, confusion, disorientation, hallucinations, hypertension, and sweating. The symptoms described in the question match those of DT, which is a medical emergency requiring immediate treatment.

 

Note -

 

Timeline of symptoms associated with withdrawal in a chronic alcoholic:

 

  • Tremors: Occur within 6-8 hours after the last drink.
  • Hallucinations: Appear around 12 hours post-drinking.
  • Seizures: Occur between 12-48 hours after the last alcohol consumption.
  • Delirium Tremens: Develops within 2-3 days after the last drink.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke's encephalopathy: This condition is caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1) and is characterized by confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. It does not typically present as acutely as described and does not fit the timeline of 2-3 days after alcohol withdrawal.

 

Option B. Korsakoff's psychosis: This is a chronic condition often following Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by severe memory impairment and confabulation. It does not present acutely within a few days of alcohol withdrawal.

 

Option C. Magnan's symptoms: These symptoms are associated with cocaine intoxication and include tactile hallucinations such as the sensation of insects crawling on or under the skin. This does not fit the description of alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically occurs 2 to 3 days after the last drink and includes symptoms like agitation, confusion, hallucinations, hypertension, and sweating.

questions.text: All of the following are considered premalignant conditions of the stomach, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hiatus hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Premalignant conditions of the stomach are pathological changes that increase the risk of developing gastric cancer. Among the options given, hiatus hernia does not carry a significant increased risk of gastric malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric ulcer - TRUE premalignant condition. Gastric ulcers have malignant potential, unlike duodenal ulcers. Chronic gastric ulcers may undergo malignant transformation, which is why multiple biopsies are recommended for all gastric ulcers to exclude malignancy.

 

Option B. Pernicious anemia and achlorhydria - TRUE premalignant condition. Autoimmune gastritis leads to parietal cell destruction, causing achlorhydria and intrinsic factor deficiency (leading to pernicious anemia). Patients with pernicious anemia have a 2-3 times increased risk of developing gastric cancer.

 

Option D. Atrophic gastritis - TRUE premalignant condition. Atrophic gastritis, particularly when associated with intestinal metaplasia, is a well-established precursor to gastric cancer. Chronic atrophic gastritis leads to loss of gastric glands and development of intestinal metaplasia, which can progress to dysplasia and cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While gastric ulcers, pernicious anemia with achlorhydria, and atrophic gastritis are established premalignant conditions that increase the risk of gastric cancer, hiatus hernia is a structural abnormality that is not directly associated with increased malignant potential in the stomach.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with swelling in the right femur for 6 months. He complaints of severe pain in the thigh which dramatically improves with intake of aspirin. The biopsy image from the lesion is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoid osteoma

 

  • This benign bone tumor is smaller in size, usually < 2 cm, and is commonly located in the cortex of long bones.
  • Femoral diaphysis is the most common location.
  • It is characterized histologically by a nidus surrounded by sclerotic bone.
  • A unique feature is that the pain worsens at night and gets a dramatic relief with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as aspirin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Osteosarcoma: A malignant tumor characterized by the direct formation of bone or osteoid tissue by tumor cells. It often appears in the metaphysis of long bones such as the femur, tibia, and humerus, primarily affecting children and young adults. Almost all patients with high-grade osteosarcoma report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis. May respond to NSAIDs like aspirin, but the response is often transient. Histologically, osteoid production from the tumor cells is seen. This osteoid matrix presents as calcification.

 

 

Option. C. Osteochondroma: A common benign bone growth that consists of a cartilage-capped bony projection or outgrowth on the surface of bones (exostosis). It typically arises from the metaphysis near the growth plate of long bones, particularly around the knee and shoulder. Usually asymptomatic, but may cause pain if the tumor becomes large or if it irritates nearby structures. Pathology and histology of an osteochondroma reveal a cap of benign hyaline cartilage resembling a disorganized growth plate, covered peripherally by perichondrium.

 

 

Option. D. Ewing's Sarcoma: A highly aggressive, malignant bone tumor that affects mostly children and adolescents. It can occur in any bone but is most often found in long bones and the pelvic region. Histologically, it features small, round, blue cells. Typically presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass. May respond to NSAIDs, but the response is often transient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The distinctive clinical presentation of relief with aspirin strongly points to an osteoid osteoma, especially when correlated with the biopsy findings suggestive of this benign condition.

questions.text: A patient presents with a slowly progressive swelling that has been noticeable for the past 18 months. The swelling exhibits variable consistency, with some areas feeling hard and others feeling soft, image of patient is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis for this clinical presentation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Explanation:

 

The case scenario and image showing a swelling lifting the ear lobe are suggestive of a pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common benign tumors of the salivary glands, with the parotid gland being the most frequent site. These tumors are encapsulated and exhibit a mixed cellular composition, leading to a variable consistency, which is reflected in their name "pleomorphic." Clinically, they present as painless, slow-growing masses. The characteristic lift of the earlobe due to the swelling is a classic sign of a parotid gland tumor. Untreated pleomorphic adenomas may undergo malignant transformation, hence surgical excision is typically recommended.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Jaw Tumor: Jaw tumors, particularly those of the mandible or maxilla, are often bony growths or related to the teeth (odontogenic tumors). While they can cause facial asymmetry, they are usually centered around the bones and are not typically located in the parotid gland region. These tumors tend to be hard and lack the variable consistency described in the clinical presentation.

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts are benign cystic tumors containing skin appendages (such as hair follicles), and sometimes hair, teeth, or sebum. They are typically congenital and found on the face, neck, or ovary. While they can appear on the face or neck, the described clinical presentation is less suggestive of a dermoid cyst compared to a pleomorphic adenoma. Dermoid cysts often show indentation due to putty material.

 

Option D. Sebaceous cyst: Also known as an epidermal cyst, a sebaceous cyst is a benign growth arising from blocked sebaceous glands, often containing a thick, cheese-like material. Sebaceous cysts can appear almost anywhere on the body where sebaceous glands are found, including the face, and often show a black punctum. However, the described clinical presentation and duration better match a pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands, typically presenting as a painless, slow-growing mass with variable consistency and often lifting the earlobe due to its location in the parotid gland.

questions.text: Epithelial lining of trachea is made of which type of cells? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified ciliated columnar cells

 

The epithelial lining of the trachea consists of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium appears to be layered (stratified) due to the varying positions of the nuclei within the cells, but in reality, all cells are attached to the basement membrane, making it a "pseudostratified" layer. The presence of cilia on the apical surface of the cells helps in the movement of mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract, which is crucial for maintaining respiratory health.

 

 

 

Note - Kartagener Syndrome which is characterized by a triad of situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and infertility. This syndrome is linked to defects in the ciliary structure and function, known as primary ciliary dyskinesia, affecting not just respiratory epithelium but also other ciliated cells in the body, such as those in the reproductive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciliated columnar cells: Although the cells are ciliated, they are not simply columnar; they are pseudostratified columnar cells.

 

Option B. Non-ciliated cuboidal cells: This type of epithelium is typically found in smaller ducts and glands, not in the respiratory tract, making it incorrect for the trachea.

 

Option D. Simple columnar cells: This type of epithelium is found in areas like the gastrointestinal tract, where absorption is a key function. It is not characteristic of the trachea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trachea is lined with pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium, which plays a critical role in trapping and moving particles out of the respiratory system to keep the airways clear.

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. The post-op x-ray is shown below. The fracture will heal by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary healing

 

The x-ray shows a fracture that has been treated with plating. This suggests the fracture is undergoing primary healing, which occurs when there is rigid fixation (such as with plates). In primary healing, no callus formation is seen because the bone edges are closely approximated and there is minimal micromotion. Healing occurs through direct bone formation, and intramembranous ossification can be part of this process. However, the overall mechanism here is primary healing, which is specifically associated with rigid internal fixation like plating.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creeping substitution: This refers to a bone graft healing mechanism where old bone is replaced by new bone. It does not apply to fracture healing in the context of this case.

 

Option B. Intramembranous ossification: While intramembranous ossification can be involved in primary bone healing, it is not the comprehensive mechanism. The broader term is primary healing, which includes processes like intramembranous ossification but is driven by rigid fixation.

 

Option D. Secondary healing: This involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion at the fracture site, as seen with casting or nailing. This is not applicable in this case, where rigid fixation (plating) is used, leading to primary healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary healing occurs with rigid fixation (such as plating) and involves direct bone formation without callus formation. Secondary healing involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion, typically seen with casts or nailing.

questions.text: During an ocular examination, the ophthalmologist observes the presence of the shifting fluid sign in the patient. This finding suggests that the patient might have which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exudative RD

 

  • Shifting fluid is a hallmark feature of serous or exudative retinal detachment.
  • In serous retinal detachment, there is subretinal accumulation of serous fluid mostly due to breakdown in blood-retinal barrier.
  • Fluid shifts to the dependent portion when head position is altered.
  • Serous retinal detachment has a smooth convex configuration and lacks a retinal tear or preretinal traction.
  • Rhegmatogenous RD presents with tobacco dust in anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells, and retinal breaks.
  • Traction RD has a concave configuration, absent breaks, and severely reduced retinal mobility.
  • Shifting fluid is absent in traction RD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traction RD: Tractional retinal detachment is caused by fibrovascular proliferation and contraction of epiretinal membranes, leading to mechanical traction on the retina. It has a concave configuration and lacks shifting fluid due to the tethering of the retina by fibrous tissue. Retinal mobility is severely reduced, and retinal breaks are usually absent.

 

Option C. Rhegmatogenous RD: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment occurs due to a retinal tear or hole that allows vitreous fluid to enter the subretinal space. It presents with signs such as tobacco dust (Shafer's sign) in the anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood, inflammatory cells, and visible retinal breaks. Shifting fluid is not a characteristic feature of rhegmatogenous RD.

 

Option D. Retinal Dialysis: Retinal dialysis is a type of retinal tear that typically occurs at the ora serrata, where the retina is particularly thin and prone to tearing. It is most often seen in younger patients or those who have experienced trauma. Shifting fluid is not a specific feature of retinal dialysis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old male pt presented to your clinic with persistent non-pitting edema in their lower extremities as shown below. What could be the most likely reason for this symptom? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the likeliest cause.
  • It involves the build-up of protein-rich fluid in tissue interstitial spaces.
  • It shows typical “non-pitting” edema in the second stage of lymphedema.
  • Filariasis is the most common etiology.
  • In severe and long standing cases, skin changes are seen giving the limb an appearance of “Elephantiasis”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arterial Disorders: Arterial disorders may lead to symptoms such as leg pain, intermittent claudication, and tissue damage due to reduced blood supply. Edema is uncommon.

 

Option C. Venous Disorders: These disorders can encompass conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), varicose veins, chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), and venous ulcers. Venous disorders may result in symptoms like leg swelling, pain, and skin changes, and they can vary in severity. No evidence of skin changes associated with varicose veins are seen.

 

Option D. Coronary Heart Disease: Coronary heart disease (CHD), also known as coronary artery disease (CAD), is a common heart condition where the coronary arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle become narrowed or blocked due to the buildup of fatty deposits (atherosclerosis). CAD may lead to heart failure leading to bilateral lower limb pitting edema, which is not seen in the case above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphedema is characterized by non-pitting edema due to the accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the tissue interstitial spaces. It can lead to significant swelling and skin changes, particularly in the lower extremities, distinguishing it from other causes of edema.

questions.text: Bowing of legs with bleeding gums is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin C

 

Explanation:

 

Bowing of legs can be mistakenly attributed to vitamin D deficiency, which typically causes rickets in children.

 

However, the presence of bleeding gums points specifically to vitamin C deficiency.

 

Vitamin C is crucial for collagen synthesis and other structural aspects of bone formation. This deficiency, known as scurvy, involves various skeletal changes including defective osteoid matrix formation and osteolysis, beyond just the commonly noted bleeding gums. The combined symptoms of bowing of legs and bleeding gums can indeed suggest a scenario where vitamin C deficiency plays a contributory role alongside other deficiencies like vitamin D.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A: Incorrect because Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision and epithelial tissues, not typically associated with bleeding gums or significant skeletal changes like bowing of legs.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Incorrect as Vitamin E deficiency generally leads to neurological problems and muscle weakness, not directly linked with bleeding gums or bone deformities.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Incorrect because while Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, its deficiency is not typically associated with bowing of legs; it would rather lead to bleeding issues without the skeletal deformities noted here.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vitamin C deficiency can cause bleeding gums and is associated with significant bone structure changes, leading to conditions like scurvy that may present with skeletal deformities such as bowing of legs.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of heavy metal toxicity. Laboratory investigations confirm the presence of heavy metal ions in the patient's bloodstream. The medical team is considering chelation therapy to bind and facilitate the excretion of the toxic metals. Which of the following agents is NOT typically used for the treatment of heavy metal toxicity? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oximes

 

The agents listed are all chelating agents except for oximes, which are not typically used for heavy metal toxicity.

 

Oximes, such as pralidoxime, are used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase that has been inactivated by organophosphate poisoning, not heavy metal toxicity. They do not have a chelating effect on heavy metals and are therefore not used in the treatment of heavy metal toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BAL (British Anti-Lewisite): BAL is a chelating agent used to treat arsenic, gold, and mercury poisoning. It works by binding to the heavy metal ions, forming a complex that can be excreted from the body.

 

Option C. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid): EDTA is another chelating agent that binds to lead and other heavy metals. It is used in cases of lead poisoning and can also chelate other metals such as zinc, cadmium, and manganese.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is used in the treatment of copper toxicity, such as Wilson's disease, and can also chelate mercury and lead. It binds to the metals and helps remove them from the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oximes are not used for heavy metal chelation and are specifically used to treat organophosphate poisoning by reactivating acetylcholinesterase. Chelating agents like BAL, EDTA, and penicillamine are typically used for heavy metal toxicity.

questions.text: Which structure forms the lateral boundary of the Hasselbach’s triangle? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior epigastric vessels

 

Explanation:

 

The lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle is formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

 

The Hasselbalch triangle is an important anatomical region related to the anterior abdominal wall and is relevant to the understanding of inguinal hernias.

 

The Hasselbalch triangle's boundaries are formed by the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, the rectus abdominis muscle medially, and the inguinal ligament forming the base.

 

This triangle is discussed in the context of inguinal hernias, where a direct inguinal hernia occurs when the hernia protrudes through the Hasselbalch triangle, while an indirect inguinal hernia occurs outside of this triangle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vessels: The femoral vessels are not mentioned as forming the lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle.

 

Option C. Inguinal ligament: The inguinal ligament forms the base of the Hasselbalch triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Option D. Rectus abdominis: The rectus abdominis muscle forms the medial boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle, an important anatomical region related to inguinal hernias, is formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

questions.text: Outbreak of diarrhea. Rice water stool in nature. Pathogen exhibited darting motility. What is the organism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vibrio cholerae

 

Characteristic features of Vibrio cholera:

 

  • Rice water stool: This is a characteristic symptom of cholera, which is caused by Vibrio cholerae. The stool looks similar to the water left after washing rice, which is a key indicator of this infection.
  • Darting motility: Vibrio cholerae exhibits a unique form of motility known as darting motility. This type of movement resembles a shooting star, which is rapid and straight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salmonella typhi: This bacterium causes typhoid fever, not characterized by rice water stools or darting motility.

 

Option C. E. coli: While certain strains of E. coli can cause diarrhea, they do not produce rice water stools nor do they exhibit darting motility. Their motility is usually peritrichous flagella-based.

 

Option D. Shigella dysentriae: This pathogen causes dysentery, characterized by bloody diarrhea, not rice water stools. It also does not exhibit darting motility; its movement is typically more sluggish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of motility:

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a limbal scar presents to the ophthalmology clinic with moderately defective vision for both near and far. Clinical examination reveals a wide and deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and a dark pupillary reflex. Vision of 6/6 is achieved with a corrective lens of +11D. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aphakia

 

The clinical presentation strongly indicates Aphakia. The key diagnostic findings include deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis (tremulousness of iris), and dark pupillary reflex (aphakic pupil). Additionally, the high hyperopic correction (+11D) needed to achieve normal vision is characteristic of aphakia. Presence of Limbal scar in his given scenario indicates a post-surgical condition differentiating it from simple posterior dislocation. Posterior dislocation occurs when all zonules are severed, allowing the lens to fall into the vitreous cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudophakia: This refers to a state where an artificial intraocular lens has been implanted. There's no mention of any surgical history or presence of an IOL, making this diagnosis incorrect.

 

Option C. Hypermetropia: While the patient requires a hyperopic correction (+11D), this is far beyond typical hypermetropia. Primary hypermetropia wouldn't explain the deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, or dark pupillary reflex.

 

Option D. Posterior Dislocation of Lens: While sharing similar features (deep AC, iridodonesis), the lens would still be present in the vitreous cavity. On fundus examination, a posteriorly dislocated lens would be visible. Would be described as "lens in vitreous cavity" rather than merely a dark pupillary reflex

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aphakia presents with the classic triad of deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and dark pupillary reflex, requiring high plus power correction (+10D to +12D) due to the complete absence of the crystalline lens that normally contributes +15-16D to the eye's refractive power.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with long-standing type 2 diabetes came to the OPD with complaints of fatigue and frequent urination. His FBS = 144 mg/dl & PPBS = 210 mg/dl. What is the target HbA1c for adequate control of diabetes? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) < 7.0

 

Explanation

 

The universal target HbA1c for adequate control of diabetes is generally less than 7%. This target helps in reducing the risk of diabetic complications. However, it is important to consider individual patient factors when setting targets.

 

In very old and frail patients, a less stringent target of less than 8% may be appropriate to avoid the risks of hypoglycemia and other complications. Since the options do not include 8%, the standard target of less than 7% is selected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The target HbA1c for most patients with diabetes to ensure adequate control is less than 7%, though this may vary based on individual patient circumstances.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary identification made by a CBNAAT or GeneXpert? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTB + Rifampicin resistance

 

Explanation:

 

The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT), also known as GeneXpert, is a molecular diagnostic test used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin.

 

The key points are:

 

  1. CBNAAT or GeneXpert is a molecular method based on real-time PCR that can detect the presence of MTB. (Detection  limit  à about 131 bacilli/mL of specimen)
  2. In addition to detecting MTB, it can also detect resistance to the drug rifampicin by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance
  3. CBNAAT/GeneXpert primarily identifies the presence of MTB and rifampicin resistance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: While CBNAAT can detect the presence of MTB, it also provides information on rifampicin resistance, making this option incomplete.

 

Option C. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not directly detect resistance to isoniazid, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.

 

Option D. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Ethambutol resistance: CBNAAT does not detect resistance to ethambutol, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT or GeneXpert) is a molecular diagnostic tool that primarily identifies the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene.

 

Additional Information –

 

Laboratory Diagnosis

 

  1. Direct microscopy by acid-fast staining
  2. Kinyoun’s Cold acid-fast Staining
  3. Fluorescence Staining
  4. Culture Methods
    1. Conventional Media
    2. Automated Liquid Culture  à BACTEC MGIT
  5. Molecular Methods

  6. Polymerase Chain reaction (PCR)

  7. Automated real Time PCR  à  CBNAAT, TrueNat

 

RNTCP diagnostic algorithm -

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fornix

 

  • The image given shows a midsagittal section of the brain.
  • The structure marked is the Fornix.
  • The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter located in the medial surface of the brain, just below the corpus callosum.
  • The fornix is an important part of the limbic system, and it is the hippocampus's largest single pathway, connecting it to various subcortical structures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pineal gland: It is a small endocrine gland located in a midsagittal section, seen as a small structure located posterior to the third ventricle in the midline, projecting from the diencephalon. Its main hormone, melatonin, plays a critical role in the regulation of circadian rhythms, influencing sleep-wake cycles.

 

Option B. Falx cerebri: It is a dural fold that descends vertically in the longitudinal fissure, which divides the cerebral hemispheres. In a midsagittal view, it appears as a thin membrane running vertically between the left and right cerebral hemispheres. The falx cerebri attaches anteriorly to the crista galli of the ethmoid bone and posteriorly to the internal occipital protuberance.

 

Option D. Pituitary gland: It is often referred to as the "master gland", is an endocrine gland responsible for producing several critical hormones that regulate growth, blood pressure, and other functions. In the midsagittal view, the pituitary gland is located at the base of the brain, hanging down from a stalk (infundibulum) from the hypothalamus. This gland rests within a depression in the sphenoid bone called the sella turcica.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers that acts as a major output tract from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies and then onto the thalamus. In the midsagittal section, the fornix is seen as an arching structure that lies inferior to the corpus callosum, the massive fiber tract connecting the two cerebral hemispheres. The body of the fornix travels anteriorly and inferiorly, eventually dividing into left and right columns which curve downward in front of the thalamus.

questions.text: A child presents with generalized edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urinalysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nephrotic syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of a child with generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies is highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome, which is a glomerular disease characterized by heavy proteinuria. The diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome is based on the triad of hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL), edema, and hyperlipidemia (cholesterol >200 mg/dL) in addition to proteinuria >3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein:creatinine ratio >2.

 

Causes of Nephrotic Syndrome:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Nephritic syndrome: Nephritic syndrome classically presents with tea- or cola-colored urine (hematuria), edema, hypertension, and oliguria.

 

Conditions which present as glomerulonephritis:

 

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • IgA nephropathy (Option D)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) nephritis

 

Option C. Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome also referred to as anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease, is an autoimmune disease that affects both the kidneys and lungs by the formation of autoantibodies that attack their basement membranes. Plasmapheresis is recommended in patients with pauci-immune crescentic GN and Goodpasture syndrome.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, is a kidney disorder that occurs when immunoglobulin A (IgA), a protein that helps the body fight infections, settles in the kidneys. This can cause inflammation that, over time, can affect the kidneys' ability to filter waste from the blood. IgA nephropathy is one of the most common glomerulonephritis, a type of kidney disease that affects the glomeruli, the tiny filters within the kidneys that filter waste and excess fluids from the blood.

 

Some common features of IgA nephropathy include:

 

  1. Hematuria: The most common symptom is the presence of blood in the urine (hematuria), which can make the urine appear pink or cola-colored.
  2. Proteinuria: Protein in the urine (proteinuria) may also occur but is typically less significant than in other kidney diseases.
  3. High Blood Pressure: Some individuals may develop high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies in urinalysis

questions.text: What is the most appropriate initial treatment for an infertile woman diagnosed with bilateral cornual block on Hysterosalpingography? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hysteroscopic Cannulation

 

Hysteroscopic cannulation is the most appropriate first-line treatment for proximal (cornual) tubal blockage. For proximal tubal occlusion, the treatment options include hysteroscopic re-cannulation or ART. When a proximal tubal block is identified on HSG, this may sometimes be due to mucus plugging or tubal spasm rather than true anatomical obstruction. Hysteroscopic cannulation with a guide wire under direct visualization can restore tubal patency in approximately 85% of cases with an overall pregnancy rate of 45-60%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In vitro fertilization (IVF): While IVF is an effective treatment for tubal factor infertility, it should not be the first-line approach for cornual block. Tubal surgery may be tried for mild proximal tubal block before resorting to ART. IVF is more appropriate after failed cannulation attempts or with more complex tubal disease.

 

Option B. Salpingectomy followed by IVF: This aggressive approach is inappropriate for cornual blockage. Salpingectomy is indicated primarily for hydrosalpinx before IVF. There is no indication for removing tubes with only cornual blockage.

 

Option C. Salpingostomy followed by IVF: Salpingostomy is a surgical procedure indicated for distal tubal obstruction, not proximal/cornual blockage. Salpingostomy creates a new opening in a completely occluded tube and is performed at the abdominal ostium, not the cornual end.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proximal tubal cannulation is the preferred initial treatment for cornual tubal blockage as it is less invasive than other surgical options, can be performed under hysteroscopic guidance, and has reasonable success rates before proceeding to more complex interventions like IVF.

choices.text: Failure to acidify urine to a pH of < 5
Increased risk of formation of urinary stones

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Type 1 Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) is incorrect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Associated with Hyperkalemia

 

Type 1 RTA (distal RTA) is characterized by hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia. The classic distal RTA presents with hypokalemia, a non-AG metabolic acidosis, low urinary NH4+ excretion (positive UAG, low urine [NH4+]), and inappropriately high urine pH (pH > 5.5). Hyperkalemia is instead a characteristic feature of Type 4 RTA, which involves generalized distal nephron dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Associated with nephrolithiasis: Type 1 RTA patients typically have hypocitraturia and hypercalciuria, which lead to nephrolithiasis, nephrocalcinosis, and bone disease. The reduced urinary citrate and increased calcium excretion create an environment favorable for stone formation.

 

Option B. Failure to acidify urine to a pH of < 5:  A hallmark of Type 1 RTA is the inability to acidify urine below pH 5.5 despite systemic acidosis. This occurs due to a defect in H+ secretion in the distal tubule, leading to persistently elevated urine pH even when blood pH is low.

 

Option C. Increased risk of formation of urinary stones:  The combination of hypocitraturia (reduced urinary citrate, which normally inhibits stone formation) and hypercalciuria (increased calcium excretion) in Type 1 RTA significantly increases the risk of calcium phosphate stone formation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Type 1 (distal) RTA is characterized by hypokalemia, non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, inappropriately high urine pH (>5.5), hypocitraturia, and hypercalciuria, which contribute to the development of nephrolithiasis and nephrocalcinosis. Hyperkalemia is instead a feature of Type 4 RTA.

questions.text: The earliest sign of pregnancy on Trans Vaginal Scan is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gestational sac

 

On transvaginal ultrasound (TVS), the gestational sac is the first visible sign of pregnancy, appearing at 5 weeks of gestation. This is approximately one week earlier than when it becomes visible on transabdominal scan (TAS, visible at 6 weeks). The gestational sac appears as an anechoic structure within the endometrial cavity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Yolk sac: This is incorrect as the yolk sac appears at 5.5 weeks on TVS, after the gestational sac is visible.

 

Option C. Fetal pole: This is incorrect as the fetal pole appears at 6 weeks on TVS, after both the gestational sac and yolk sac are visible.

 

Option D. Cardiac activity: This is incorrect as cardiac activity also becomes visible at 6 weeks on TVS, along with the fetal pole, making it one of the later findings in early pregnancy ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The chronological order of appearance of early pregnancy structures on TVS:

 

  • Gestational sac: 5 weeks
  • Yolk sac: 5.5 weeks
  • Fetal pole with cardiac activity: 6 weeks 
  • On trans-abdominal scan; these structures appear 1 week later

choices.text: Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

questions.text: Which of the following is the etiology of the Werner syndrome with premature aging?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

 

This is the correct explanation for the etiology of Werner syndrome. Individuals with Werner syndrome have mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a helicase enzyme involved in DNA repair and maintenance. These mutations lead to the loss of helicase function and result in the accumulation of DNA damage and shortened telomeres, contributing to premature aging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased length of telomere: This option is not the cause of Werner syndrome. In fact, individuals with Werner syndrome have shortened telomeres, not increased length. Telomeres are the protective caps at the end of chromosomes, and their shortening is associated with aging and age-related diseases.

 

Option C. Increased advanced glycation end products: Advanced glycation end products (AGEs) are associated with various age-related conditions, but they are not the primary cause of Werner syndrome. While AGEs can contribute to cellular damage, they are not the central mechanism behind this syndrome.

 

Option D. Decreased lipid peroxidation: Decreased lipid peroxidation is not the primary cause of Werner syndrome. Lipid peroxidation refers to the oxidative damage to lipids (fats), and although oxidative stress is involved in aging, it is not the primary driver of Werner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Werner syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by premature aging. It is caused by mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a protein called Werner syndrome ATP-dependent helicase (WRN). The WRN protein is involved in DNA repair, maintenance of genome stability, and telomere maintenance. One of the other functions of this protein is DNA helicase.

 

In Werner syndrome, there is a loss of function of the WRN protein, leading to problems with DNA repair and telomere maintenance. Telomeres are the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, and they shorten with each cell division. In Werner syndrome, there is accelerated telomere shortening, and this contributes to premature aging. There is also increased risk of cancer.

 

Ref: Harper’s 31st/e pg. 370

questions.text: External beam radiotherapy uses: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Co60

 

External beam radiotherapy, a cornerstone in the treatment of various cancers, utilizes high-energy beams to target and destroy cancer cells.

 

Co60 is a common radioisotope used in external beam radiotherapy due to its high-energy gamma rays, which are effective at penetrating tissues to treat tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cobalt-59 (Co59): Co59 is not used in radiation therapy; it is a stable isotope of cobalt.

 

Option C. Strontium: Strontium isotopes (like Sr-89) are used in the treatment of bone metastases, not typically in external beam radiotherapy. They help alleviate pain by targeting cancerous cells in the bone.

 

Option D. Phosphorus: Phosphorus (typically P-32) is used in radiopharmaceuticals for treating specific types of blood disorders and polycythemia vera, not in external beam radiotherapy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

EBRT uses Cobalt 60 as the radioisotope.

questions.text: A patient presenting with bleeding gums and easy bruisability was diagnosed with scurvy. What is the biochemical basis of scurvy?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defective collagen formation

 

Scurvy is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), which is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in the synthesis of collagen. Collagen is a crucial protein for the structural integrity of connective tissues, including blood vessels, skin, and gums. In the absence of sufficient vitamin C, collagen synthesis is impaired, leading to weakened blood vessels, bleeding gums, and easy bruising..

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low calcium levels do not cause scurvy; they may contribute to other clinical conditions like Muscle cramps and stiffness, Tingling and Numbness, Tetany.

 

Option C. Vitamin K deficiency leads to the inhibition of clotting factors and cause bleeding tendencies.

 

Option D. Vitamin A deficiency causes hyperkeratosis and epithelial changes, such as xerosis and Bitot's spots, and night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Based on the given information, the most likely diagnosis for the 3-year-old male with buccal mucosa findings followed by a rash after three days is Measles.

 

  • Measles is a viral illness that commonly affects children. It typically starts with flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes.
  • One of the hallmark signs of measles is the presence of Koplik spots, which are small, white, grain-like lesions that appear on the buccal mucosa.
  • A rash usually follows the appearance of Koplik spots. This rash typically starts on the face and neck and then spreads to the rest of the body.
  • If you suspect that a child has measles, it is essential to isolate them and refer them to a healthcare facility for further evaluation and treatment.
  • Lymphadenopathy may also be present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leukoplakia: Leukoplakia is a benign condition characterized by white patches on the mucous membranes. It is not associated with fever and rash.

 

Option C. Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci and presents with a URI (upper respiratory infection) and a sandpaper-like rash. It does not have Koplik spots.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, and conjunctivitis but lacks Koplik spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles is characterized by the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa followed by a widespread rash, starting from the face and neck.

questions.text: Splenectomy is contraindicated in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

 

Bone marrow failure often seen in aplastic anemia, involves the failure of the bone marrow to produce sufficient blood cells. The spleen is not involved in this pathology, so splenectomy would not be beneficial. The problem lies within the bone marrow, not the spleen, making splenectomy contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenic rupture: Splenectomy is commonly indicated in cases of splenic rupture, whether due to trauma or iatrogenic causes, to prevent life-threatening hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: In cases of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), splenectomy can be an effective treatment option to achieve durable remission, although it is not the first-line treatment.

 

  • Corticosteroids and other treatments are often tried first.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia: Splenectomy may be indicated in hairy cell leukemia in cases of massive splenomegaly or persistent cytopenias to alleviate symptoms and improve blood counts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenectomy is contraindicated in bone marrow failure, as the underlying issue resides in the bone marrow's inability to produce blood cells.

questions.text: A child was born after 8 months of the father’s death. Grandparents filed a case that the baby might not be their son’s, but DNA came positive. What is such a child called? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posthumous child

 

A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of either parent. In this scenario, the child was born 8 months after the father's death, which fits the definition of a posthumous child. The grandparents doubted the child’s legitimacy, but DNA testing confirmed the biological connection, validating the child's status as the deceased father's offspring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suppositious child: A suppositious child is a term used to describe a fraudulent or fake child who is falsely presented as an heir, often to claim property or inheritance. This does not apply in this case because the DNA test confirmed the child’s legitimacy as the biological offspring.

 

Option B. Fictitious child: A fictitious child is purely an imaginary or invented figure that does not exist in reality, often found in literature or imagination. This term is unrelated to the case as it refers to nonexistent entities, unlike the real, biologically confirmed child in question.

 

Option D. Illegitimate child: An illegitimate child is one born outside of marriage or not legally recognized as belonging to the mother's husband. In this case, the DNA test confirmed that the child is indeed the biological offspring of the deceased father, making the term irrelevant here.

 

Educational Objective:


A posthumous child is one born after the death of a parent, as seen in this scenario where the child was born 8 months after the father's death.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman complains of leakage of urine on straining and coughing. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stress urinary incontinence

 

Explanation:

 

Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) occurs when there is involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as straining, coughing, sneezing, or exercising. This condition is often due to weakness of the pelvic floor muscles and the urethral sphincter, which fail to properly support the bladder and urethra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urge urinary incontinence: This type of incontinence is characterized by a sudden and intense urge to urinate, followed by involuntary leakage of urine. It is commonly associated with an overactive bladder.

 

Option C. Mixed urinary incontinence: This occurs when a person experiences symptoms of both stress and urge urinary incontinence.

 

Option D. Overflow incontinence: This type occurs when the bladder fails to empty completely, leading to leakage of small amounts of urine. It is often associated with bladder outlet obstruction or neurological conditions affecting bladder function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stress urinary incontinence is diagnosed when an individual experiences leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as straining or coughing, due to weakened pelvic floor muscles and urethral sphincter.

questions.text: Defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme is associated with?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1 Tyrosinemia

 

  • True. Type 1 Tyrosinemia, also known as hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 (HT1), is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH). This deficiency leads to the accumulation of toxic substances in the body, causing various health problems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 2 Tyrosinemia: False. Type 2 Tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine aminotransferase, not fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase.

 

Option C. Type 3 Tyrosinemia: False. Type 3 Tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase, not fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase.

 

Option D. Type 4 Tyrosinemia: False. There is no Type 4 Tyrosinemia. The primary types of Tyrosinemia are Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatorenal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type I) aka Tyrosinosis –

 

  • Autosomal recessive, most common type of tyrosinemia.
  • Due to a deficiency of enzyme fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase.
  • Symptoms manifest by the first 6 months of life and death occurs rapidly. Cabbage like odor and hypoglycemia and eventual liver failure are seen. There may be mild mental retardation.
  • Urine contains tyrosine, para-hydroxyphenyl pyruvic acid (p-HPPA) and hydroxyphenyl lactic acid; and serum shows tyrosine.
  • Tyrosine and phenylalanine restricted diet is advised.

 

Oculocutaneous Tyrosinemia/ Richner-Hanhart Syndrome (Tyrosinemia Type II) is due to deficiency of tyrosine amino transferase (tyrosine transaminase). Mental retardation, keratosis of palmar surface, painful corneal lesions and photophobia are seen. There is increased excretion of tyrosine and tyramine in urine. A diet low in protein is advised.

 

Neonatal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type III) is due to the absence of the enzyme para-hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase. This deficiency may cause transient hypertyrosinemia in the newborn; this will respond to administration of ascorbic acid and dietary protein restriction.

questions.text: Oil drop cataract is seen in which condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactosemia

 

An oil drop cataract is a specific type of cataract that is characteristically seen in patients with galactosemia. Galactosemia is an inherited disorder of galactose metabolism, where the body is unable to properly process galactose, a sugar found in milk. As a result of the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites in the lens of the eye, a cataract forms that resembles an oil droplet when viewed under certain lighting conditions. This cataract is often congenital or develops early in life, making it a common cause of pediatric cataracts.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. While it affects various organs, it does not typically cause oil drop cataracts.

 

Option C. Tay-Sachs disease: Tay-Sachs disease is another lysosomal storage disorder, caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A. It primarily affects the central nervous system and does not cause oil drop cataracts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oil drop cataracts are a hallmark feature of galactosemia, an inherited disorder affecting galactose metabolism, and they can present as congenital or developmental cataracts in pediatric patients.

choices.text: Leave the IUCD in situ

questions.text: A 26-year-old conceives on the IUCD. Wants to continue pregnancy. Next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Remove the IUCD gently

 

The Ans. is Remove the IUCD gently. When a woman becomes pregnant with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in place and wishes to continue the pregnancy, the IUCD should be removed if possible. Leaving the IUCD in situ is associated with risks such as preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, and potential fetal anomalies. While removing the IUCD does carry a slightly increased risk of miscarriage, the overall benefits of removal outweigh the risks of leaving it in place. Removal should be done carefully, with appropriate counseling provided to the patient about the potential risks involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leave the IUCD in situ: Leaving the IUCD in place is not recommended as it can lead to complications like preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, and other pregnancy complications. Therefore, it should be removed if the patient wishes to continue the pregnancy.

 

Option C. MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy): MTP is not appropriate in this scenario because the patient wishes to continue with the pregnancy. The focus should be on managing the pregnancy safely with the IUCD removed.

 

Option D. Progesterone support: Progesterone support is not indicated in this case as it does not address the main issue, which is the presence of the IUCD and its associated risks if left in place during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a pregnancy occurs with an IUCD in place and the patient wishes to continue, the IUCD should be removed gently to minimize risks associated with leaving it in situ.

questions.text: Which sampling method is predominantly utilized by the World Health Organization (WHO) to evaluate immunization coverage levels? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Cluster sampling

 

  • Cluster Random Sampling (CRS) is specifically used for immunization coverage evaluation. The WHO uses the "30 x 07" technique, where 30 clusters are selected with 7 children (aged 12-23 months) examined in each cluster.
  • This standardized approach involves selecting 30 clusters by systematic random sampling and then examining the first 7 children in each cluster, creating a total sample size of 210.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systematic sampling: While systematic random sampling may be used to select the 30 clusters in the first stage of cluster sampling, it is not the primary methodology recommended for immunization coverage evaluation.

 

Option B. Stratified sampling: For immunization coverage evaluation specifically, stratified sampling has a higher error rate compared to cluster sampling and is not the predominant method used.

 

Option C. Random sampling: Simple random sampling has a much higher error rate (±30%) compared to cluster random sampling (±5%), making it less suitable for immunization evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cluster Random Sampling provides the most reliable results for immunization coverage evaluation with an error rate of only ±5%, making it the preferred methodology using the standardized "30 x 7" approach.

questions.text: A patient presents with diminution of vision. He has a H/o ATT intake. The causative drug is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is the most likely causative drug for vision problems in patients taking anti-tubercular therapy (ATT). It can cause toxic optic neuropathy, leading to diminution of vision. This side effect is dose-dependent and usually reversible if detected early and the drug is discontinued. Ethambutol primarily affects the optic nerve, causing decreased visual acuity, altered color perception (especially red-green color blindness), and central scotomas.

 

Toxic Amblyopia caused by drugs:

 

  • Ethambutol
  • Tobacco
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Quinine
  • Ethyl Alcohol
  • Methyl Alcohol

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiazinamide: This drug is not commonly used in ATT and is not typically associated with vision problems.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: While an important component of ATT, rifampicin is not primarily associated with vision changes. Its main side effects include hepatotoxicity and orange discoloration of body fluids.

 

Option C. Isoniazid: Although isoniazid can cause peripheral neuropathy, it is not typically associated with optic neuropathy or vision changes. Its main neurological side effect is peripheral neuropathy, which can be prevented by administering pyridoxine (vitamin B6).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is the anti-tubercular drug most commonly associated with toxic optic neuropathy, causing diminution of vision in patients on ATT. Regular ophthalmic monitoring is crucial for patients on ethambutol to detect early signs of toxicity

questions.text: A middle aged cement factory worker has developed mesothelioma. This is likely to be associated with: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestosis

 

Mesothelioma is a malignant tumor of the pleura (or less commonly, the peritoneum). The development of mesothelioma is closely linked with exposure to asbestos, which is commonly encountered in certain occupational settings, including cement factories.

 

Asbestosis:

 

  • Pathology: Asbestosis refers to chronic lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibers. The fibers can cause inflammation and scarring of lung tissue, leading to a restrictive lung disease.
  • Complications: Prolonged exposure to asbestos can lead to the development of mesothelioma, a malignant tumor of the pleura or peritoneum.
  • Occupational Exposure: Cement factory workers, construction workers, and shipbuilders are at higher risk of asbestos exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: Caused by inhalation of silica dust, leading to nodular pulmonary fibrosis. Not directly associated with mesothelioma.

 

Option C. Anthracosis: Associated with coal dust inhalation, leading to coal worker's pneumoconiosis, not mesothelioma.

 

Option D. Byssinosis: Associated with cotton dust inhalation, leading to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, not mesothelioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mesothelioma is strongly associated with asbestos exposure, commonly found in occupations such as cement factory work, construction, and shipbuilding. Asbestosis can lead to significant complications, including mesothelioma.

 

Asbestos is a fibrous silicate mineral used in insulation, construction, and cement manufacturing.

 

  • Inhaled asbestos fibers lodge in the lungs and pleura, causing:
  • Interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Pleural plaques
  • Mesothelioma
  • Increased risk of bronchogenic carcinoma
  • Even minimal exposure can be dangerous over time.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever for 5 days and you are suspecting enteric fever. What is the best way to diagnose? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blood Cultures

 

Explanation:

 

Enteric fever, commonly known as typhoid fever, is typically caused by the bacteria Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi. The best diagnostic method depends on the stage of the disease.

 

For a patient presenting with fever for 5 days (in the first week of illness), blood cultures are the most reliable diagnostic method. During the first week, the bacteria are most likely to be present in the bloodstream, making blood cultures highly effective for identifying the pathogen.

 

Key points:

 

  • Blood cultures: The best diagnostic method for enteric fever during the first week of illness, as the bacteria are present in the blood.
  • Bone marrow cultures: While they have the highest sensitivity at any stage of the disease, they are more invasive and less commonly performed compared to blood cultures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urine cultures: These are not typically useful in the early stages of enteric fever and are more relevant in the later stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Widal test: This serological test detects antibodies against Salmonella antigens, but it is less specific and sensitive, especially in the early stages. It also has a higher rate of false positives and is not recommended as the primary diagnostic tool in the first week.

 

Option D. Stool cultures: These can be useful later in the disease when the bacteria are shed in the stool, but they are not the best diagnostic method during the first week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For diagnosing enteric fever in the first week of illness, blood cultures are the most effective and reliable method.

questions.text: Injury to which of the following nerves most commonly results in foot drop? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common peroneal nerve

 

Common Peroneal Nerve (also known as Common Fibular Nerve) is the nerve primarily responsible for foot drop when injured.

 

  • Origin: The common peroneal nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve, which splits into the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve near the apex of the popliteal fossa.
  • Function: It innervates the muscles of the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, such as the tibialis anterior, which dorsiflexes the ankle. An injury to this nerve can result in the inability to dorsiflex the foot, leading to "foot drop."
  • Common injury sites: This nerve can be compromised at the fibular head where it is superficial, making it susceptible to injuries.      

 

 

Hence, injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to:

 

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss
    • Anterior and lateral side of the leg
    • Dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Femoral Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Arises from the lumbar plexus and is composed of fibers from the L2 to L4 nerve roots.
  • Function: Primarily innervates the anterior thigh muscles like the quadriceps, which are responsible for knee extension. It also provides sensation to the anterior thigh and medial leg.
  • If injured: A person may have difficulty in extending the knee and reduced sensation in the innervation area, but it will not cause foot drop.

 

Option C. Tibial Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Another branch of the sciatic nerve.
  • Function: It innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg, which are primarily responsible for plantarflexion of the ankle and flexion of the toes.
  • If injured: A person may have difficulty in plantarflexing the ankle or flexing the toes and may have a loss of sensation in the sole of the foot, but foot drop is not a symptom.

 

Option D. Sciatic Nerve:

 

  • Origin: The largest nerve in the body, originating from the sacral plexus with roots from L4 to S3.
  • Function: Innervates much of the posterior thigh, all of the leg except for a small medial area, and most of the foot.
  • If injured: Since the sciatic nerve gives rise to both the tibial and common peroneal nerves, injury can cause a range of motor and sensory deficits in the leg, depending on the injury's location. However, an injury specifically leading to foot drop would more directly implicate its common peroneal branch rather than the entire sciatic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a screening examination conducted on a population of 1000 individuals for diabetes mellitus (DM), 90 individuals tested positive. Subsequently, a gold standard test for DM was performed, identifying 100 positive cases. What is the calculated sensitivity? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 90/100

 

In given question, the following data are provided:

 

Total population = 1000

 

Total diseased people = 100 (identified by gold standard test)

 

Total number of diabetics identified initially = 90, thus

 

total positive identified by screening test =90

 

 

Therefore:

 

Sensitivity = TP/(TP+FN) =90/ (90+10) = 90/100 = 90%

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensitivity is the proportion of true positive cases correctly identified by a screening test out of all actual positive cases identified by the gold standard test.

questions.text: A patient consumed a toxic substance and presented with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and hypocalcemia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethylene Glycol

 

Ethylene glycol is a toxic substance commonly found in antifreeze. When ingested, it is metabolized into toxic metabolites, including oxalic acid. Oxalic acid binds to calcium in the blood, forming calcium oxalate crystals, which leads to hypocalcemia—a significant clue in diagnosing ethylene glycol poisoning. Additionally, ethylene glycol poisoning often presents with symptoms like tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension, as seen in this case.

 

Hypocalcemia is a critical diagnostic feature because it specifically points toward ethylene glycol ingestion compared to other toxic substances. Early recognition and treatment are essential to prevent severe complications, including kidney failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron poisoning typically presents with gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain) and systemic toxicity such as metabolic acidosis. Hypocalcemia is not a hallmark feature of iron poisoning, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Methanol: Methanol poisoning can cause metabolic acidosis, visual disturbances ("snowfield" vision), and central nervous system depression. Hypocalcemia is not commonly associated with methanol toxicity, which makes this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin toxicity commonly presents with gastrointestinal symptoms, confusion, visual changes, and arrhythmias. While it can cause hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia is not a feature of digoxin poisoning, eliminating this option as the Ans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by hypocalcemia due to the formation of calcium oxalate crystals and presents with symptoms such as tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension.

questions.text: The observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match the ECG findings of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

 

Stress cardiomyopathy commonly affects Women (post-menopausal) > men predominantly due to emotional > physical stress. Neurogenic myocardial stunning occurs leading to heart failure.

 

Beta-2 (Gs stimulation) is present at base and b2 (Gi) activation leads to hypercontractility at the base & apical ballooning giving a typical Takotsubo appearance.

 

ECG mimics ACS, RWMA not corresponding to single artery territory, normal CAG with Mild troponin elevation are clues to takotsubo.

 

Treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors if non-responsive. Carries good prognosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic dysfunction on but NOT significant ECG changes.

 

Option C: Brugada syndrome is a channelopathy caused due LOF (loss of function) mutation of cardiac SCN5a (Sodium channel) resulting in transmural voltage difference between endocardium-epicardium causing ventricular arrhythmias which initially affects the RV myocardium.

 

 

Option D: Tamponade occurs due to rapid accumulation of fluid/blood in the pericardium producing the characteristic Beck triad (↑JVP ↓ Heart sounds ↓ BP).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy should be considered when a patient's clinical presentation includes myocardial stunning that does not correspond to ECG findings typical of a myocardial infarction, especially in the context of recent significant emotional or physical stress.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Cardiomyopathies/Chap 259

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and something coming out of the vagina. Her last childbirth was 10 years back. On bimanual palpation, the uterus is palpable. On examination, the cervix admits 1 finger, and the following is seen. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroid polyp

 

The clinical presentation, including heavy menstrual bleeding, the presence of a vaginal mass, and the fact that the uterus is palpable on bimanual examination, strongly suggests a fibroid polyp. A fibroid polyp is a type of submucosal fibroid that protrudes into the uterine cavity and may extend through the cervix into the vagina. It can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, including intermenstrual bleeding, due to the exposed surface of the polyp that can easily get eroded.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenomyoma: This is incorrect. Adenomyoma, a localized form of adenomyosis, typically presents similarly to fibroids but does not cause a vaginal mass. The uterus would also be enlarged, and the cervix would not be open to admit a finger.

 

Option C. Intramural fibroid: This is incorrect. Intramural fibroids grow within the muscular wall of the uterus and do not typically protrude through the cervix to present as a vaginal mass. The uterus would be enlarged, and the cervix would not be open.

 

Option D. Inversion: This is incorrect. Uterine inversion usually occurs postpartum, often immediately after childbirth, or it can present as a chronic condition that began after a previous childbirth. In inversion, the uterus is typically not palpable on bimanual examination because it has turned inside out. The cervix would not admit a finger as the entire uterus is inside out, blocking access.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fibroid polyp presents with heavy menstrual bleeding, a palpable uterus on bimanual examination, and a protruding mass in the vagina due to the fibroid extending through the cervix

choices.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue
Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required

questions.text: A patient came to the medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na+ levels are found to be 155 mEq/L, urine osmolality was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DDAVP supplementation for lifelong

 

The patient's presentation of polyuria and low urine osmolality (200 mOsm/L) with hypernatremia (Na+ 155 mEq/L) is indicative of diabetes insipidus (DI). Given the history of total hypophysectomy, this is most likely central diabetes insipidus (CDI), where the pituitary gland no longer produces antidiuretic hormone (ADH, also known as vasopressin).

 

In CDI, the definitive treatment is desmopressin (DDAVP), a synthetic analog of ADH. Desmopressin helps to reduce urine output and correct hypernatremia by promoting water reabsorption in the kidneys. Since the condition is permanent due to the hypophysectomy, lifelong supplementation with desmopressin is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue: Discontinuing DDAVP after 2 weeks is not appropriate as the patient will continue to suffer from polyuria and hypernatremia due to the lack of ADH.

 

Option C. Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required: This option is incorrect as the patient's symptoms and lab findings clearly indicate the need for treatment.

 

Option D. Thiazides for 2 weeks: Thiazides are used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) to reduce urine output by increasing ADH sensitivity. However, in central diabetes insipidus, thiazides are not effective because the issue is the absence of ADH, not a problem with the kidneys' response to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with central diabetes insipidus following total hypophysectomy, lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) supplementation is required to manage symptoms and prevent complications from persistent polyuria and hypernatremia.

questions.text: Which defect is shown below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Homonymous hemianopia

 

The image shows a visual field defect characterized by loss of vision on the right side of the visual field in both eyes, which is termed as homonymous hemianopia. The term "homonymous" indicates that the defect is on the same side of the visual field in both eyes, while "hemianopia" refers to the loss of half of the visual field.

 

This pattern is typically caused by a lesion in the left optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe, which affects the visual field on the opposite side (right side in this case). The defect is contralateral to the side of the lesion, meaning that a left-sided lesion will produce a right-sided visual field loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bitemporal hemianopia: This condition involves the loss of vision in the temporal (outer) fields of both eyes, usually due to a lesion at the optic chiasm, such as from a pituitary tumor. The image does not show this pattern, as only the right visual fields are affected, not the outer fields.

 

Option B. Binasal hemianopia: This defect involves the loss of vision in the nasal (inner) fields of both eyes, often resulting from bilateral optic nerve compression. The visual defect in the image does not match this pattern, as it shows only right-sided field loss.

 

Option C. Altitudinal defect: This type of defect affects the upper or lower half of the visual field in one or both eyes, commonly seen in conditions like ischemic optic neuropathy. The image does not depict an upper or lower field defect; rather, it shows a loss on the right side of both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homonymous hemianopia is characterized by the loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes and is typically caused by lesions in the contralateral optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe.

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift.

 

  • It is an airway management technique to open up the collapsed airway.
  • This maneuver involves tilting the patient's head backward by gently lifting the chin upward.
  • It is used to open the airway and clear any potential obstruction in the upper part of the throat.
  • This is a basic technique used in CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) to help with ventilation.

 

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: The jaw thrust maneuver is used to open the airway in a patient with a suspected cervical spine injury. Instead of tilting the head backward, the anesthesiologist uses their fingers to push the patient's jaw forward. This technique avoids movement of the neck and is often used when spinal injury is a concern.

 

 

Option C. Head extension: Head extension involves simply tilting the patient's head backward to open the airway. It is similar to the head tilt, chin lift maneuver, but it focuses more on extending the neck to clear the airway.

 

 

Option D. In line manual stabilization: This technique is used to stabilize the cervical spine, especially in cases of suspected neck injuries. It involves maintaining the head and neck in a neutral, aligned position to prevent further injury during maneuvers like intubation. This is typically done by an assistant while another healthcare provider performs airway management.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift.
  • It is an airway management technique to open up the collapsed airway.

choices.text: Bipartite patella; X-ray of other knee

questions.text: Shown below is an X-ray of a patient with history of a chronic knee pain. True statement concerning the X-ray shown would be: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bipartite patella; X-ray other knee

 

BIPARTITE PATELLA

 

  • It is the congenital fragmentation of patella.
  • In this condition, the patella is made up of two separate bones instead of one.
  • It occurs when the patella fails to fuse properly during development, leading to a bipartite appearance.
  • This condition is typically asymptomatic and may go unnoticed for many years.
  • In some cases, it can cause pain, swelling, or discomfort, especially during physical activity.
  • The X-ray of opposite knee must be taken as the condition is bilateral in 50% of cases and this condition is more common in males than females.

 

 

  • Management usually involves conservative measures to alleviate symptoms like rest, ice, and physical therapy to strengthen the Quadriceps muscles, and reduce stress on the patella.
  • In more severe cases, a brace may be recommended to provide additional support and reduce stress on the patella.
  • Pain medications and anti-inflammatory drugs may also be prescribed to relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  • If conservative measures fail to provide relief, surgery may be considered. Surgery typically involves removing the smaller bone fragment and smoothing the joint surface to reduce friction and alleviate pain.
  • In rare cases, surgery may involve fusing the two patellar fragments together to create a single patella.
  • With appropriate treatment, most people can return to their normal activities without significant limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avulsion fracture; cylindrical cast. In avulsion fracture of PCL alone, the non-operative treatment relies on restoration of tibiofemoral relationship with immobilization, followed by physiotherapy. In the first 6 weeks, immobilization and limited weight bearing is achieved using a cylindrical cast in 15° flexion or with posterior support in the form of extension or dynamic anterior drawer brace to prevent subluxation of tibia.

 

 

Option C. Avulsion fracture; wire fixation. K-wire fixation is done for distal phalanx base avulsion fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows bipartite patella which is a congenital fragmentation of patella i.e., the patella is made of two separate bones instead of one.
  • In this condition, it is always recommended to get an x-ray of the other knee also as this condition is bilateral in most cases.
  • It is treated by surgical removal of the smaller bone fragment when the conservative methods fail to provide relief.

questions.text: Which of these disorders was earlier known as minimal brain dysfunction?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder

 

Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) was earlier referred to as minimal brain dysfunction. ADHD is characterized by symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dyslexia is a specific learning disorder that affects reading, despite normal intelligence. It is characterized by difficulties with accurate and/or fluent word recognition and by poor spelling and decoding abilities.

 

Option C. Mental sub normality is an outdated term, previously used to describe intellectual disabilities or developmental delays.

 

Option D. Oligophrenia is an old term that was used to describe intellectual disability or mental retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ADHD, formerly known as minimal brain dysfunction, is characterized by symptoms of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity. Diagnosis requires symptoms before age 12 in multiple settings. Treatment commonly involves stimulant medications and behavioral therapy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1171.

questions.text: Which of the following is a manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bitot's spots

 

Bitot's spots are a characteristic manifestation of vitamin A deficiency. These are foamy, triangular, silvery-white spots that appear on the conjunctiva, typically on the temporal side of the cornea. They are composed of keratin debris and are a sign of xerophthalmia (dry eye) associated with vitamin A deficiency.
