Bitot's spots are an important clinical sign used to diagnose vitamin A deficiency, especially in developing countries where this nutritional deficiency is more common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vogt's striae: Incorrect. These are vertical lines seen in the cornea of patients with keratoconus, a progressive eye disease that causes thinning and bulging of the cornea. They are not related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option C. Arlt's line: Incorrect. This refers to a linear scar on the inner surface of the upper eyelid, typically seen in patients with trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. It is not associated with vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option D. Horner tantra dots: Incorrect. This appears to be a misspelling of "Horner-Trantas dots," which are white, chalky accumulations of eosinophils and epithelial cells at the limbus (the border between the cornea and the sclera). They are commonly seen in patients with vernal keratoconjunctivitis, an allergic eye condition, and are not related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitot's spots are a characteristic ocular manifestation of vitamin A deficiency, appearing as foamy, silvery-white spots on the conjunctiva.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer develops diffuse hair loss following the treatment. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anagen effluvium

 

This is a classic case of anagen effluvium where:

 

  • Hair loss occurs 3-4 weeks after chemotherapy/radiotherapy
  • Actively dividing anagen hair follicles (80-90% of scalp hair) are directly damaged
  • Complete destruction of anagen phase leads to diffuse hair loss
  • No conversion of anagen to telogen phase occurs
  • Loss is abrupt and extensive due to direct damage to growing follicles

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Telogen effluvium

 

  • Occurs 3 months after a stressful trigger (not immediately)
  • Triggers include surgery, pregnancy, infections like typhoid/dengue/COVID
  • Involves premature conversion of anagen to telogen phase
  • Not associated with direct follicular damage


 

Option C. Trichotillomania

 

  • Associated with psychiatric issues/OCD
  • Compulsive hair pulling disorder
  • Shows incomplete patch of hair loss with varying lengths
  • Not related to chemotherapy

 


Option D. Alopecia areata

 

  • Presents as well-defined patches of complete hair loss
  • Autoimmune targeting of anagen hair bulb
  • Shows exclamation mark hairs at margins
  • No association with chemotherapy


 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Chemotherapy-induced hair loss is due to anagen effluvium, where rapidly dividing hair follicle cells are damaged. 
  • Hair loss starts within weeks of chemotherapy initiation and is diffuse and non-scarring. 
  • Hair typically regrows within a few months after stopping chemotherapy.

questions.text: Identify the brain malformation shown in the given MRI image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arnold Chiari malformation

 

Arnold Chiari malformation is a condition where there is herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This malformation is characterized by downward displacement of the cerebellum, particularly the tonsils, which can be observed on MRI scans as a distinctive pattern of herniation below the level of the foramen magnum. The provided radiograph shows this exact presentation, with cerebellar tissue extending through the foramen magnum, indicating Arnold Chiari malformation.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus callosal agenesis: This condition involves the complete or partial absence of the corpus callosum, the structure that connects the two cerebral hemispheres. This malformation would not present with cerebellar herniation on imaging but would show an absence of the corpus callosum on MRI.

 

Option B. Vein of Galen malformation: This is a vascular malformation involving an abnormal connection between cerebral arteries and veins. It would appear as a large, dilated venous structure on imaging and would not show herniation of the cerebellum.

 

Option C. Dandy Walker malformation: This condition is characterized by cystic enlargement of the fourth ventricle, partial or complete absence of the cerebellar vermis, and enlargement of the posterior fossa.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arnold Chiari malformation is identified by the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, visible on MRI scans as the downward displacement of cerebellar tissue.

choices.text: It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus
Mucus secreting foveolar cells are characteristic
Alcian blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimen
It is a reversible cell adaptation

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Barrett's esophagus?(NEET  PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucus-secreting foveolar cells are characteristic

 

Mucus-secreting foveolar cells are characteristic: This statement is not true. Foveolar cells are a feature of the normal gastric mucosa, and their presence in biopsy specimens from the esophagus is not characteristic of Barrett's esophagus. Mucus-secreting goblet cells (not foveolar cells) are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the intestinal metaplasia of the esophagus: This statement is true. Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the normal squamous epithelium of the lower esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium with intestinal features.

 

Option C. Alcian blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimens: This statement is true. Alcian blue is a stain used to detect the presence of acid mucins in tissue samples, which are a feature of the columnar epithelium seen in Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option D. It is a reversible cell adaptation: This statement is true. As all metaplasia are reversible, Barrett's esophagus is also reversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett's esophagus is characterized by intestinal metaplasia of the esophageal epithelium, specifically with goblet cells, and is diagnosed using Alcian blue staining.

questions.text: Which compound among the options is predominantly responsible for the disinfectant quality to bleaching powder? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hypochlorous acid

 

The primary reason for the disinfectant ability of bleaching powder stems from the activity of hypochlorous acid, which is responsible for its effectiveness. It surpasses hypochlorite ions in effectiveness by a factor of 70-80.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypochlorite Ion (OCl⁻): While it does have disinfectant properties, it is much less effective compared to hypochlorous acid.

 

Option B. Hydrochloric Acid (HCl): This is a byproduct of the reaction between chlorine and water but does not contribute significantly to the disinfectant quality.

 

Option D. Chloride Ion (Cl⁻): This is also a byproduct of the disinfection process and does not play a direct role in the disinfectant action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleaching powder (CaOCl2)

 

  • 2.5 gms of bleaching powder is sufficient to disinfect 1000L of water.

 

Mechanism of action:

 

  • CHLORINE + IMPURITIES à DESTRUCTION Add some additional Cl2 [free residual Cl2]
  • Main disinfecting action of chlorine in water is due to HYPOCHLOROUS ACID [HOCL] [90% of disinfection] + Hypochlorite ions [10% of disinfection]

 

H2O + Cl → HCI + HOCI HOCI → H + OCI

questions.text: A husband and wife presented to the outpatient department with complaints of the husband's premature ejaculation, which is leading to frequent conflicts between them. Which of the following non-pharmacological techniques is most appropriate for treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squeeze Technique

 

For the management of premature ejaculation, the Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method that is often recommended. This technique involves sexual stimulation until the individual is close to ejaculation. At that point, the partner squeezes the shaft of the penis (coronal ridge of glans) for several seconds, which can delay ejaculation. This process is repeated several times before ejaculation is allowed to occur. The Squeeze Technique helps in increasing the time before ejaculation and is directly targeted at managing premature ejaculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sensate Focus Technique: While this technique, which involves non-genital pleasuring, can be helpful in reducing performance anxiety and improving sexual communication, it is not specifically designed for the treatment of premature ejaculation. It is useful for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Exposure and Response Prevention: This is a technique used primarily in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder and is not typically employed for premature ejaculation.

 

Option D. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): CBT can be useful for addressing underlying psychological issues contributing to sexual dysfunction, but it is a more general approach and not as specifically targeted for premature ejaculation as the Squeeze Technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method effective in the management of premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the penis before the point of ejaculation to delay it and can be repeated several times to increase the time before ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 531.
